title.narrative: Pakistan: Second Punjab Education Sector Project

description.narrative: The Project Development Objective (PDO) of PESP II is to support the education sector reform program of the Government of Punjab toincrease child school participation (at multiple levels) and student achievement.

condition.narrative: Finance Agreement :Annual Examinations/Assessments | Description :GoPunjab to carry out annual province-wide examinations ofstudents in grades 5 and 8 and district-representative diagnostic assessments. | Frequency :Yearly

Finance Agreement :Audit Reporting | Description :GoPunjab to submit the audit reports covering the overall budgetary expendituresof GoPunjab for said Fiscal Year, as well as the individual audits corresponding to each of its District governments within 1 monthas of the receipt of the audits reports from the Auditor General of Pakistan. | Frequency :Yearly

Finance Agreement :Complaints Redressal | Description :GoPunjab to strengthen and update the Complaints Redressal System currentlyoperating within the School Education Department (SED). | Frequency :Yearly

Finance Agreement :Disclosure of Procurement Activities | Description :GoPunjab to (i) establish a system for the handling ofprocurement complaints; and (ii) maintain a procurement documentation and recordkeeping system, including a publicly-accessiblewebsite. | Frequency :Yearly

Finance Agreement :Environmental and Social Management Framework (ESMF) Compliance | Description :Government of Pakistan andGoPunjab to ensure that the activities under the Project: (i) are carried out in accordance with the Environmental and SocialManagement Framework; and (ii) do not entail land acquisition or give rise to Displaced Persons. | Frequency :Yearly

Finance Agreement :Financial Reporting | Description :GoPunjab to prepare quarterly consolidated budget execution reports (“BERs”)setting out values of budgets, actual expenditures incurred, per month, per budget line, for the whole education sector, with acover note summarizing budget allocations and utilization in the Eligible Expenditure Programs (EEPs) within 30 days after the endof each calendar quarter. | Frequency :Quarterly

Finance Agreement :Information and Communications | Description :GoPunjab to carry out a stakeholder information and communicationsneeds assessment, and thereafter develop an information and communications strategy. | Due Date :30-Dec-2012

Finance Agreement :MoU with Punjab Education Foundation | Description :GoPunjab to cause SED to enter into a Memorandum ofUnderstanding with the Punjab Education Foundation (PEF) detailing the responsibilities of SED and PEF in the financing andimplementation of PEF’s private school subsidy and student vouchers programs. | Due Date :31-May-2013

Finance Agreement :Program Management | Description :GoPunjab to maintain a Provincial Steering Committee, a Program Monitoring andImplementation Unit (PMIU), and District Review Committees (DRCs) in all provincial districts. | Frequency :Yearly

Finance Agreement :Regular Program Monitoring | Description :GoPunjab to (i) ensure that all government schools are surveyed byCMMF, at least once in each calendar quarter; and (ii) make the information so collected publicly available within 60 days of theend of the quarter. | Frequency :Quarterly

Finance Agreement :School Council Procurement Compliance | Description :GoPunjab to ensure that school councils abide by thesimplified Financial Management and Procurement Guidelines for School Councils. | Frequency :Yearly

Finance Agreement :Strengthening Program Monitoring | Description :GoPunjab to ensure that SED prepares and implements aninstitutional plan for strengthening the capacity of the Chief Minister’s Monitoring Force (CMMF). | Due Date :31-Dec-2012

Finance Agreement :Strengthening of Examination and Assessment Systems | Description :GoPunjab to prepare a plan for strengtheningthe Punjab Examination Commission and the Punjab Education Assessment System. | Due Date :31-Dec-2012

Finance Agreement :Teacher Certification Systems | Description :GoPunjab to: (i) prepare a policy framework for the introduction ofa new teacher certification and licensing regime; (ii) prepare an implementation plan for the introduction of such regime; and(iii) submit to Punjab’s Provincial Assembly, for its consideration,a draft law for the establishment of a teacher certificationand licensing body. | Due Date :15-May-2015

title.narrative: Number of additional qualified primary teachers resulting from project interventions.
Vouchers for private schooling: number of beneficiaries
Stipends for girls for secondary schooling (number of beneficiaries)
Utility of the learning assessment system
Nonsalary expenditures: Share of nonsalary expenditures in total recurrent expenditures
Net enrollment rate, primary, ages 6–10 years
System for learning assessment at the primary level
DLI 10: Stipends for secondary school girls

baseline.value: Attendance-tied stipend benefits offered on a quarterly basis to beneficiary girls in grades 6–10 in government schools in targetedstipend districts. Concerns of limited program efficiency and effectiveness due to present benefit level and structure. Stipendsadministration currently handled by district education administrations and stipends delivery handled by the government postalsystem. Concerns of delays and potential errors and leakage.

target.value: Attendance-tied supplemental stipend benefits following agreed benefit structure offered to beneficiary girls in grades 6–10 in allrural government schools in existing stipends districts. Intended beneficiary girls in grades 6–10 in 100% of urban governmentschools and 50% of rural government schools receive stipend benefits through agreed branchless banking options.

actual.value: Supplemental stipends provided to female students in all rural government schools in existing stipend districts. Branchless bankingcoverage targets have been met.

title.narrative: DLI 8: Provision and use of system and school performance information

baseline.value: Delivery of information of any kind across the government school system is ad hoc and piecemeal, and the presentation and contentof delivered information are weak, impairing evidence-based decision making to improve system and school performance.

target.value: District and school performance report cards, following agreed format and contents, prepared and delivered on a quarterly basis toall district education administrations and on a semiannual basis to 100% of primary, middle, and high schools and school councils,and openly displayed at schools.

actual.value: District report cards disseminated to all 36 districts and all middle, high and urban primary schools.

baseline.value: Field-based system of teaching advisory support to teachers at school has been introduced province-wide but operational capacityand performance are currently deficient.

target.value: Primary grades of 100% of achievement-poor schools in all 36 districts actively covered by the strengthened field-based system forteaching advisory support to teachers at school.

actual.value: Primary grades of close to 100% of achievement poor schools in all 36 districts actively covered by the strengthened field-basedsystem for teaching advisory support to teachers at school.

baseline.value: No school-level budgeting, planning, and execution for primary, middle and elementary schools.

target.value: (1) School-specific nonsalary budgets prepared in the preceding year approved, disbursed and openly displayed at schools;school-specific nonsalary budgets for FY2015/16 prepared in accordance with agreed funding formula and submitted for inclusion inFY2015/16 district budgets for all 36 districts; and expenditure review conducted by a third party.

actual.value: Non salary budgets for 18 districts transferred as per need to school accounts for first quarter. School specific non salarybudgets have been prepared for all 36 districts of the province as per the agreed DLI for FY 2014/15 and funds have beentransferred to schools. A total demand of PKR 14 billion to meet non salary related expenditure in FY2015/16 has been agreed by thePunjab government. The Third Party Expenditure review has been completed and was found acceptable to the Bank.

baseline.value: Present recruitment is objective but is not needs-based; in addition, the screening is primarily based on qualifications, whichappear to be weak indicators of competency.

target.value: All teachers, both subject-specific and general, recruited to fill confirmed school-specific, rationalized needs, conditional onclearing a recruitment test based on teacher standards approved by SED.

actual.value: 33832 teachers recruited to fill rationalized, school-speciifc needs after clearing a recruitment test.

baseline.value: Schools councils formed province-wide, annual grants for school development offered, and community mobilization, formation, andcapacity development facilitated by contracted NGOs. School-council performance presently impaired by limited interest, capacity,and powers.

target.value: Reconstitution and operation of school councils in accordance with rules and powers in revised school-council policy, supported bya new capacity development program, in at least 50% of schools in all districts, and grant expenditures reviewed by a third party.

actual.value: Implemented in 50% of schools in 36 districts. A Third Party Expenditure review has been completed.

baseline.value: Teaching posts are not allocated at the school level for primary, middle, and elementary schools and teachers are not necessarilyposted on the basis of enrollment and other needs.

target.value: Allocation of sanctioned teaching posts to schools in accordance with agreed school-specific, needs-based formula completed, andteacher rationalization and recruitment against school-specific, needs-based teaching posts implemented in 27 districts

actual.value: Teaching posts rationalized in all 36 districts. Third Party Validation report of the rationalization exercise has been completedand validates this result.

baseline.value: Two bonus programs were introduced: “high-achievers” and “improvers”. GoPunjab is to discontinue the high-achievers program due topoor returns arising from design and implementation issues. The improvers program rewards teachers on the basis of changes instudent enrollment and achievement and is to be continued, with increased experimentation to arrive at sound teacher incentive paydesigns.

target.value: Continued implementation of adapted teacher performance bonus program following new value-added model in targeted governmentprimary schools in at least 6 achievement-poor districts, consistent with agreed impact evaluation design.

actual.value: The program was implemented as per the design. The existing improvers program was implemented in 3 districts, while the adaptedimprovers program was implemented in 3 additional districts. Funds for the bonuses were transferred by the Finance Department intothe Special Drawing Accounts of the relevant districts and onwards to the personal bank accounts of teachers

baseline.value: Vouchers to attend private schools offered to children from disadvantaged households in poor areas in 17 district capitals. Programis of small scale and present program design and administration features potentially arrest returns.

target.value: Vouchers to attend private schools under a quality-assurance system expanded to cover additional disadvantaged children in 36districts, in accordance with agreed adapted voucher program, and consistent with agreed impact evaluation design.

title.narrative: Average share of correct answers, independent test, grade 3
